<s> woodville was the son of poor clergyman and had received classical education </s>
<s> he was one of those very few whom fortune favours from their birth on whom she bestows all gifts of intellect and person with profusion that knew no bounds and whom under her peculiar protection no imperfection however slight or disappointment however transitory has leave to touch </s>
<s> she seemed to have formed his mind of that excellence which no dross can tarnish and his understanding was such that no error could pervert </s>
<s> his genius was transcendant and when it rose as bright star in the east all eyes were turned towards it in admiration </s>

<s> the fields of fancy it was in rome the queen of the world that suffered misfortune that reduced me to misery despair the bright sun deep azure sky were oppressive but nought was so hateful as the voice of man loved to walk by the shores of the tiber which were solitary if the sirocco blew to see the swift clouds pass over st </s>
<s> peters and the many domes of rome or if the sun shone turned my eyes from the sky whose light was too dazzling gay to be reflected in my tearful eyes turned them to the river whose swift course was as the speedy departure of happiness and whose turbid colour was gloomy as grief whether slept know not or whether it was in one of those many hours which spent seated on the ground my mind chaos of despair my eyes for ever wet by tears but was here visited by lovely spirit whom have ever worshiped who tried to repay my adoration by diverting my mind from the hideous memories that racked it </s>
<s> at first indeed this wanton spirit played false part appearing with sable wings gloomy countenance seemed to take pleasure in exagerating all my miseries and as small hopes arose to snatch them from me give me in their place gigantic fears which under her fairy hand appeared close impending unavoidable sometimes she would cruelly leave me while was thus on the verge of madness and without consoling me leave me nought but heavy leaden sleep but at other times she would wilily link less unpleasing thoughts to these most dreadful ones before was aware place hopes before me futile but consoling one day this lovely spirit whose name as she told me was fantasia came to me in one of her consolotary moods her wings which seemed coloured by her tone of mind were not gay but beautiful like that of the partridge her lovely eyes although they ever burned with an unquenshable fire were shaded softened by her heavy lids the black long fringe of her eye lashes she thus addressed me you mourn for the loss of those you love </s>
<s> they are gone for ever great as my power is cannot recall them to you if indeed wave my wand over you you will fancy that you feel their gentle spirits in the soft air that steals over your cheeks the distant sound of winds waters may image to you their voices which will bid you rejoice for that they live this will not take away your grief but you will shed sweeter tears than those which full of anguish hopelessness now start from your eyes this can do also can take you to see many of my provinces my fairy lands which you have not yet visited and whose beauty will while away the heavy time have many lovely spots under my command which poets of old have visited and have seen those sights the relation of which has been as revelation to the world many spots have still in keeping of lovely fields or horrid rocks peopled by the beautiful or the tremendous which keep in reserve for my future worshippers to one of those whose grim terrors frightened sleep from the eye formerly led you but you now need more pleasing images although will not promise you to shew you any new scenes yet if lead you to one often visited by my followers you will at least see new combinations that will sooth if they do not delight you follow me alas </s>
<s> replied when have you found me slow to obey your voice some times indeed have called you you have not come but when before have not followed your slightest sign and have left what was either of joy or sorrow in our world to dwell with you in yours till you have dismissed me ever unwilling to depart but now the weight of grief that oppresses me takes from me that lightness which is necessary to follow your quick winged motions alas in the midst of my course one thought would make me droop to the ground while you would outspeed me to your kingdom of glory leave me here darkling ungrateful </s>
<s> replied the spirit do not tell you that will sustain console you my wings shall aid your heavy steps will command my winds to disperse the mist that over casts you will lead you to place where you will not hear laughter that disturbs you or see the sun that dazzles you we will choose some of the most sombre walks of the elysian fields the elysian fields exclaimed with quick scream shall then see </s>
<s> gasped could not ask that which longed to know the friendly spirit replied more gravely have told you that you will not see those whom you mourn but must away follow me or must leave you weeping deserted by the spirit that now checks your tears go replied cannot follow can only sit here grieve long to see those who are gone for ever for to nought but what has relation to them can listen the spirit left me to groan weep to wish the sun quenched in eternal darkness to accuse the air the waters all all the universe of my utter irremediable misery fantasia came again and ever when she came tempted me to follow her but as to follow her was to leave for while the thought of those loved ones whose memories were my all although they were my torment dared not go stay with me cried help me to clothe my bitter thoughts in lovelier colours give me hope although fallacious images of what has been although it never will be again diversion cannot take cruel fairy do you leave me alas all my joy fades at thy departure but may not follow thee one day after one of these combats when the spirit had left me wandered on along the banks of the river to try to disperse the excessive misery that felt untill overcome by fatigue my eyes weighed down by tears lay down under the shade of trees fell asleep slept long and when awoke knew not where was did not see the river or the distant city but lay beside lovely fountain shadowed over by willows surrounded by blooming myrtles at short distance the air seemed pierced by the spiry pines cypresses and the ground was covered by short moss sweet smelling heath the sky was blue but not dazzling like that of rome and on every side saw long allies clusters of trees with intervening lawns gently stealing rivers where am </s>
<s> exclaimed looking around me beheld fantasia she smiled as she smiled all the enchanting scene appeared lovelier rainbows played in the fountain the heath flowers at our feet appeared as if just refreshed by dew have seized you said she as you slept and will for some little time retain you as my prisoner will introduce you to some of the inhabitants of these peaceful gardens it shall not be to any whose exuberant happiness will form an pleasing contrast with your heavy grief but it shall be to those whose chief care here is to acquired knowledged sic virtue or to those who having just escaped from care pain have not yet recovered full sense of enjoyment this part of these elysian gardens is devoted to those who as before in your world wished to become wise virtuous by study action here endeavour after the same ends by contemplation they are still unknowing of their final destination but they have clear knowledge of what on earth is only supposed by some which is that their happiness now hereafter depends upon their intellectual improvement nor do they only study the forms of this universe but search deeply in their own minds and love to meet converse on all those high subjects of which the philosophers of athens loved to treat with deep feelings but with no outward circumstances to excite their passions you will perhaps imagine that their life is uniform dull but these sages are of that disposition fitted to find wisdom in every thing in every lovely colour or form ideas that excite their love besides many years are consumed before they arrive here when soul longing for knowledge pining at its narrow conceptions escapes from your earth many spirits wait to receive it and to open its eyes to the mysteries of the universe many centuries are often consumed in these travels and they at last retire here to digest their knowledge to become still wiser by thought and imagination working upon memory when the fitting period is accomplished they leave this garden to inhabit another world fitted for the reception of beings almost infinitely wise but what this world is neither can you conceive or teach you some of the spirits whom you will see here are yet unknowing in the secrets of nature they are those whom care sorrow have consumed on earth whose hearts although active in virtue have been shut through suffering from knowledge these spend sometime here to recover their equanimity to get thirst of knowledge from converse with their wiser companions they now securely hope to see again those whom they love know that it is ignorance alone that detains them from them </s>
<s> as for those who in your world knew not the loveliness of benevolence justice they are placed apart some claimed by the evil spirit in vain sought for by the good but she whose delight is to reform the wicked takes all she can delivers them to her ministers not to be punished but to be exercised instructed untill acquiring love of virtue they are fitted for these gardens where they will acquire love of knowledge as fantasia talked saw various groupes of figures as they walked among the allies of the gardens or were seated on the grassy plots either in contemplation or conversation several advanced together towards the fountain where sat as they approached observed the principal figure to be that of woman about years of age her eyes burned with deep fire and every line of her face expressed enthusiasm wisdom poetry seemed seated on her lips which were beautifully formed every motion of her limbs although not youthful was inexpressibly graceful her black hair was bound in tresses round her head and her brows were encompassed by fillet her dress was that of simple tunic bound at the waist by broad girdle and mantle which fell over her left arm she was encompassed by several youths of both sexes who appeared to hang on her words to catch the inspiration as it flowed from her with looks either of eager wonder or stedfast attention with eyes all bent towards her eloquent countenance which beamed with the mind within am going said fantasia but leave my spirit with you without which this scene wd fade away leave you in good company that female whose eyes like the loveliest planet in the heavens draw all to gaze on her is the prophetess diotima the instructress of socrates the company about her are those just escaped from the world there they were unthinking or misconducted in the pursuit of knowledge </s>
<s> she leads them to truth wisdom untill the time comes when they shall be fitted for the journey through the universe which all must one day undertake farewell and now gentlest reader must beg your indulgence am being too weak to record the words of diotima her matchless wisdom heavenly eloquence what shall repeat will be as the faint shadow of tree by moonlight some what of the form will be preserved but there will be no life in it plato alone of mortals could record the thoughts of diotima hopeless therefore shall not dwell so much on her words as on those of her pupils which being more earthly can better than hers be related by living lips diotima approached the fountain seated herself on mossy mound near it and her disciples placed themselves on the grass near her without noticing me who sat close under her she continued her discourse addressing as it happened one or other of her listeners but before attempt to repeat her words will describe the chief of these whom she appeared to wish principally to impress one was woman of about years of age in the full enjoyment of the most exquisite beauty her golden hair floated in ringlets on her shoulders her hazle eyes were shaded by heavy lids and her mouth the lips apart seemed to breathe sensibility but she appeared thoughtful unhappy her cheek was pale she seemed as if accustomed to suffer and as if the lessons she now heard were the only words of wisdom to which she had ever listened the youth beside her had far different aspect his form was emaciated nearly to shadow his features were handsome but thin worn his eyes glistened as if animating the visage of decay his forehead was expansive but there was doubt perplexity in his looks that seemed to say that although he had sought wisdom he had got entangled in some mysterious mazes from which he in vain endeavoured to extricate himself as diotima spoke his colour went came with quick changes the flexible muscles of his countenance shewed every impression that his mind received he seemed one who in life had studied hard but whose feeble frame sunk beneath the weight of the mere exertion of life the spark of intelligence burned with uncommon strength within him but that of life seemed ever on the eve of fading at present shall not describe any other of this groupe but with deep attention try to recall in my memory some of the words of diotima they were words of fire but their path is faintly marked on my recollection it requires just hand said she continuing her discourse to weigh divide the good from evil on the earth they are inextricably entangled and if you would cast away what there appears an evil multitude of beneficial causes or effects cling to it mock your labour when was on earth and have walked in solitary country during the silence of night have beheld the multitude of stars the soft radiance of the moon reflected on the sea which was studded by lovely islands when have felt the soft breeze steal across my cheek as the words of love it has soothed cherished me then my mind seemed almost to quit the body that confined it to the earth with quick mental sense to mingle with the scene that hardly saw felt then have exclaimed oh world how beautiful thou art oh brightest universe behold thy worshiper spirit of beauty of sympathy which pervades all things now lifts my soul as with wings how have you animated the light the breezes deep inexplicable spirit give me words to express my adoration my mind is hurried away but with language cannot tell how feel thy loveliness </s>
<s> silence or the song of the nightingale the momentary apparition of some bird that flies quietly past all seems animated with thee more than all the deep sky studded with worlds if the winds roared tore the sea and the dreadful lightnings seemed falling around me still love was mingled with the sacred terror felt the majesty of loveliness was deeply impressed on me so also have felt when have seen lovely countenance or heard solemn music or the eloquence of divine wisdom flowing from the lips of one of its worshippers lovely animal or even the graceful undulations of trees inanimate objects have excited in me the same deep feeling of love beauty feeling which while it made me alive eager to seek the cause animator of the scene yet satisfied me by its very depth as if had already found the solution to my enquires sic as if in feeling myself part of the great whole had found the truth secret of the universe but when retired in my cell have studied contemplated the various motions and actions in the world the weight of evil has confounded me if thought of the creation saw an eternal chain of evil linked one to the other from the great whale who in the sea swallows destroys multitudes the smaller fish that live on him also torment him to madness to the cat whose pleasure it is to torment her prey saw the whole creation filled with pain each creature seems to exist through the misery of another death havoc is the watchword of the animated world and man also even in athens the most civilized spot on the earth what multitude of mean passions envy malice restless desire to depreciate all that was great and good did see and in the dominions of the great being saw man reduced far below the animals of the field preying on one anothers sic hearts happy in the downfall of others themselves holding on with bent necks and cruel eyes to wretch more slave if possible than they to his miserable passions and if said these are the consequences of civilization turned to the savage world saw only ignorance unrepaid by any noble feeling mere animal love of life joined to low love of power fiendish love of destruction saw creature drawn on by his senses his selfish passions but untouched by aught noble or even human and then when sought for consolation in the various faculties man is possessed of which felt burning within me found that spirit of union with love beauty which formed my happiness pride degraded into superstition turned from its natural growth which could bring forth only good fruit cruelty intolerance hard tyranny was grafted on its trunk from it sprung fruit suitable to such grafts if mingled with my fellow creatures was the voice heard that of love virtue or that of selfishness vice still misery was ever joined to it the tears of mankind formed vast sea ever blown on by its sighs seldom illuminated by its smiles such taking only one side of the picture shutting wisdom from the view is just portraiture of the creation as seen on earth but when compared the good evil of the world wished to divide them into two seperate principles found them inextricably intwined together was again cast into perplexity doubt might have considered the earth as an imperfect formation where having bad materials to work on the creator could only palliate the evil effects of his combinations but saw wanton malignity in many parts particularly in the mind of man that baffled me delight in mischief love of evil for evils sake siding of the multitude dastardly applause which in their hearts the crowd gave to triumphant wick ed ness over lowly virtue that filled me with painful sensations </s>

<s> notes to the complete poetical works of percy bysshe shelley by mary </s>
<s> shelley </s>
<s> preface by mrs </s>
<s> shelley to first collected edition </s>
<s> obstacles have long existed to my presenting the public with perfect edition of shelley's poems </s>
<s> these being at last happily removed hasten to fulfil an important duty that of giving the productions of sublime genius to the world with all the correctness possible and of at the same time detailing the history of those productions as they sprang living and warm from his heart and brain </s>
<s> abstain from any remark on the occurrences of his private life except inasmuch as the passions which they engendered inspired his poetry </s>
<s> this is not the time to relate the truth and should reject any colouring of the truth </s>
<s> no account of these events has ever been given at all approaching reality in their details either as regards himself or others nor shall further allude to them than to remark that the errors of action committed by man as noble and generous as shelley may as far as he only is concerned be fearlessly avowed by those who loved him in the firm conviction that were they judged impartially his character would stand in fairer and brighter light than that of any contemporary </s>
<s> whatever faults he had ought to find extenuation among his fellows since they prove him to be human without them the exalted nature of his soul would have raised him into something divine </s>
<s> the qualities that struck any one newly introduced to shelley were first gentle and cordial goodness that animated his intercourse with warm affection and helpful sympathy </s>
<s> the other the eagerness and ardour with which he was attached to the cause of human happiness and improvement and the fervent eloquence with which he discussed such subjects </s>
<s> his conversation was marked by its happy abundance and the beautiful language in which he clothed his poetic ideas and philosophical notions </s>
<s> to defecate life of its misery and its evil was the ruling passion of his soul he dedicated to it every power of his mind every pulsation of his heart </s>
<s> he looked on political freedom as the direct agent to effect the happiness of mankind and thus any new sprung hope of liberty inspired joy and an exultation more intense and wild than he could have felt for any personal advantage </s>
<s> those who have never experienced the workings of passion on general and unselfish subjects cannot understand this and it must be difficult of comprehension to the younger generation rising around since they cannot remember the scorn and hatred with which the partisans of reform were regarded some few years ago nor the persecutions to which they were exposed </s>
<s> he had been from youth the victim of the state of feeling inspired by the reaction of the french revolution and believing firmly in the justice and excellence of his views it cannot be wondered that nature as sensitive as impetuous and as generous as his should put its whole force into the attempt to alleviate for others the evils of those systems from which he had himself suffered </s>
<s> many advantages attended his birth he spurned them all when balanced with what he considered his duties </s>
<s> he was generous to imprudence devoted to heroism </s>
<s> these characteristics breathe throughout his poetry </s>
<s> the struggle for human weal the resolution firm to martyrdom the impetuous pursuit the glad triumph in good the determination not to despair such were the features that marked those of his works which he regarded with most complacency as sustained by lofty subject and useful aim </s>
<s> in addition to these his poems may be divided into two classes the purely imaginative and those which sprang from the emotions of his heart </s>
<s> among the former may be classed the witch of atlas adonais and his latest composition left imperfect the triumph of life </s>
<s> in the first of these particularly he gave the reins to his fancy and luxuriated in every idea as it rose in all there is that sense of mystery which formed an essential portion of his perception of life clinging to the subtler inner spirit rather than to the outward form curious and metaphysical anatomy of human passion and perception </s>
<s> the second class is of course the more popular as appealing at once to emotions common to us all some of these rest on the passion of love others on grief and despondency others on the sentiments inspired by natural objects </s>
<s> shelley's conception of love was exalted absorbing allied to all that is purest and noblest in our nature and warmed by earnest passion such it appears when he gave it voice in verse </s>
<s> yet he was usually averse to expressing these feelings except when highly idealized and many of his more beautiful effusions he had cast aside unfinished and they were never seen by me till after had lost him </s>
<s> others as for instance rosalind and helen and lines written among the euganean hills found among his papers by chance and with some difficulty urged him to complete them </s>
<s> there are others such as the ode to the skylark and the cloud which in the opinion of many critics bear purer poetical stamp than any other of his productions </s>
<s> they were written as his mind prompted listening to the carolling of the bird aloft in the azure sky of italy or marking the cloud as it sped across the heavens while he floated in his boat on the thames </s>
<s> no poet was ever warmed by more genuine and unforced inspiration </s>
<s> his extreme sensibility gave the intensity of passion to his intellectual pursuits and rendered his mind keenly alive to every perception of outward objects as well as to his internal sensations </s>
<s> such gift is among the sad vicissitudes of human life the disappointments we meet and the galling sense of our own mistakes and errors fraught with pain to escape from such he delivered up his soul to poetry and felt happy when he sheltered himself from the influence of human sympathies in the wildest regions of fancy </s>
<s> his imagination has been termed too brilliant his thoughts too subtle </s>
<s> he loved to idealize reality and this is taste shared by few </s>
<s> we are willing to have our passing whims exalted into passions for this gratifies our vanity but few of us understand or sympathize with the endeavour to ally the love of abstract beauty and adoration of abstract good the to agathon kai to kalon of the socratic philosophers with our sympathies with our kind </s>
<s> in this shelley resembled plato both taking more delight in the abstract and the ideal than in the special and tangible </s>
<s> this did not result from imitation for it was not till shelley resided in italy that he made plato his study </s>
<s> he then translated his symposium and his ion and the english language boasts of no more brilliant composition than plato's praise of love translated by shelley </s>
<s> to return to his own poetry </s>
<s> the luxury of imagination which sought nothing beyond itself as child burdens itself with spring flowers thinking of no use beyond the enjoyment of gathering them often showed itself in his verses they will be only appreciated by minds which have resemblance to his own and the mystic subtlety of many of his thoughts will share the same fate </s>
<s> the metaphysical strain that characterizes much of what he has written was indeed the portion of his works to which apart from those whose scope was to awaken mankind to aspirations for what he considered the true and good he was himself particularly attached </s>
<s> there is much however that speaks to the many </s>
<s> when he would consent to dismiss these huntings after the obscure which entwined with his nature as they were he did with difficulty no poet ever expressed in sweeter more heart reaching or more passionate verse the gentler or more forcible emotions of the soul </s>
<s> wise friend once wrote to shelley you are still very young and in certain essential respects you do not yet sufficiently perceive that you are so it is seldom that the young know what youth is till they have got beyond its period and time was not given him to attain this knowledge </s>
<s> it must be remembered that there is the stamp of such inexperience on all he wrote he had not completed his nine and twentieth year when he died </s>
<s> the calm of middle life did not add the seal of the virtues which adorn maturity to those generated by the vehement spirit of youth </s>
<s> through life also he was martyr to ill health and constant pain wound up his nerves to pitch of susceptibility that rendered his views of life different from those of man in the enjoyment of healthy sensations </s>
<s> perfectly gentle and forbearing in manner he suffered good deal of internal irritability or rather excitement and his fortitude to bear was almost always on the stretch and thus during short life he had gone through more experience of sensation than many whose existence is protracted </s>
<s> if die to morrow he said on the eve of his unanticipated death have lived to be older than my father the weight of thought and feeling burdened him heavily you read his sufferings in his attenuated frame while you perceived the mastery he held over them in his animated countenance and brilliant eyes </s>
<s> he died and the world showed no outward sign </s>
<s> but his influence over mankind though slow in growth is fast augmenting and in the ameliorations that have taken place in the political state of his country we may trace in part the operation of his arduous struggles </s>
<s> his spirit gathers peace in its new state from the sense that though late his exertions were not made in vain and in the progress of the liberty he so fondly loved </s>
<s> he died and his place among those who knew him intimately has never been filled up </s>
<s> he walked beside them like spirit of good to comfort and benefit to enlighten the darkness of life with irradiations of genius to cheer it with his sympathy and love </s>
<s> any one once attached to shelley must feel all other affections however true and fond as wasted on barren soil in comparison </s>
<s> it is our best consolation to know that such pure minded and exalted being was once among us and now exists where we hope one day to join him although the intolerant in their blindness poured down anathemas the spirit of good who can judge the heart never rejected him </s>
<s> in the notes appended to the poems have endeavoured to narrate the origin and history of each </s>
<s> the loss of nearly all letters and papers which refer to his early life renders the execution more imperfect than it would otherwise have been </s>
<s> have however the liveliest recollection of all that was done and said during the period of my knowing him </s>
<s> every impression is as clear as if stamped yesterday and have no apprehension of any mistake in my statements as far as they go </s>
<s> in other respects am indeed incompetent but feel the importance of the task and regard it as my most sacred duty </s>
<s> endeavour to fulfil it in manner he would himself approve and hope in this publication to lay the first stone of monument due to shelley's genius his sufferings and his virtues se al seguir son tarda forse avverra che bel nome gentile consacrero con questa stanca penna </s>
<s> postscript in second edition of </s>
<s> in revising this new edition and carefully consulting shelley's scattered and confused papers found few fragments which had hitherto escaped me and was enabled to complete few poems hitherto left unfinished </s>
<s> what at one time escapes the searching eye dimmed by its own earnestness becomes clear at future period </s>
<s> by the aid of friend also present some poems complete and correct which hitherto have been defaced by various mistakes and omissions </s>
<s> it was suggested that the poem to the queen of my heart was falsely attributed to shelley </s>
<s> certainly find no trace of it among his papers and as those of his intimate friends whom have consulted never heard of it omit it </s>
<s> two poems are added of some length swellfoot the tyrant and peter bell the third </s>
<s> have mentioned the circumstances under which they were written in the notes and need only add that they are conceived in very different spirit from shelley's usual compositions </s>
<s> they are specimens of the burlesque and fanciful but although they adopt familiar style and homely imagery there shine through the radiance of the poet's imagination the earnest views and opinions of the politician and the moralist </s>
<s> at my request the publisher has restored the omitted passages of queen mab </s>
<s> now present this edition as complete collection of my husband's poetical works and do not foresee that can hereafter add to or take away word or line </s>

<s> shelley to the volume of posthumous poems published in </s>
<s> in nobil sangue vita umile queta ed in alto intelletto un puro core frutto senile in sul giovenil fibre in aspetto pensoso anima lieta petrarca </s>
<s> it had been my wish on presenting the public with the posthumous poems of mr shelley to have accompanied them by biographical notice as it appeared to me that at this moment narration of the events of my husband's life would come more gracefully from other hands than mine applied to mr leigh hunt </s>
<s> the distinguished friendship that mr shelley felt for him and the enthusiastic affection with which mr leigh hunt clings to his friend's memory seemed to point him out as the person best calculated for such an undertaking </s>
<s> his absence from this country which prevented our mutual explanation has unfortunately rendered my scheme abortive </s>
<s> do not doubt but that on some other occasion he will pay this tribute to his lost friend and sincerely regret that the volume which edit has not been honoured by its insertion </s>
<s> the comparative solitude in which mr shelley lived was the occasion that he was personally known to few and his fearless enthusiasm in the cause which he considered the most sacred upon earth the improvement of the moral and physical state of mankind was the chief reason why he like other illustrious reformers was pursued by hatred and calumny </s>
<s> no man was ever more devoted than he to the endeavour of making those around him happy no man ever possessed friends more unfeignedly attached to him </s>
<s> the ungrateful world did not feel his loss and the gap it made seemed to close as quickly over his memory as the murderous sea above his living frame </s>
<s> hereafter men will lament that his transcendent powers of intellect were extinguished before they had bestowed on them their choicest treasures </s>
<s> to his friends his loss is irremediable the wise the brave the gentle is gone for ever </s>
<s> he is to them as bright vision whose radiant track left behind in the memory is worth all the realities that society can afford </s>
<s> before the critics contradict me let them appeal to any one who had ever known him </s>
<s> to see him was to love him and his presence like ithuriel's spear was alone sufficient to disclose the falsehood of the tale which his enemies whispered in the ear of the ignorant world </s>
<s> his life was spent in the contemplation of nature in arduous study or in acts of kindness and affection </s>
<s> he was an elegant scholar and profound metaphysician without possessing much scientific knowledge he was unrivalled in the justness and extent of his observations on natural objects he knew every plant by its name and was familiar with the history and habits of every production of the earth he could interpret without fault each appearance in the sky and the varied phenomena of heaven and earth filled him with deep emotion </s>
<s> he made his study and reading room of the shadowed copse the stream the lake and the waterfall </s>
<s> ill health and continual pain preyed upon his powers and the solitude in which we lived particularly on our first arrival in italy although congenial to his feelings must frequently have weighed upon his spirits those beautiful and affecting lines written in dejection near naples were composed at such an interval but when in health his spirits were buoyant and youthful to an extraordinary degree </s>
<s> such was his love for nature that every page of his poetry is associated in the minds of his friends with the loveliest scenes of the countries which he inhabited </s>
<s> in early life he visited the most beautiful parts of this country and ireland </s>
<s> afterwards the alps of switzerland became his inspirers </s>
<s> prometheus unbound was written among the deserted and flower grown ruins of rome and when he made his home under the pisan hills their roofless recesses harboured him as he composed the witch of atlas adonais and hellas </s>
<s> in the wild but beautiful bay of spezzia the winds and waves which he loved became his playmates </s>
<s> his days were chiefly spent on the water the management of his boat its alterations and improvements were his principal occupation </s>
<s> at night when the unclouded moon shone on the calm sea he often went alone in his little shallop to the rocky caves that bordered it and sitting beneath their shelter wrote the triumph of life the last of his productions </s>
<s> the beauty but strangeness of this lonely place the refined pleasure which he felt in the companionship of few selected friends our entire sequestration from the rest of the world all contributed to render this period of his life one of continued enjoyment </s>
<s> am convinced that the two months we passed there were the happiest which he had ever known his health even rapidly improved and he was never better than when last saw him full of spirits and joy embark for leghorn that he might there welcome leigh hunt to italy </s>
<s> was to have accompanied him but illness confined me to my room and thus put the seal on my misfortune </s>
<s> his vessel bore out of sight with favourable wind and remained awaiting his return by the breakers of that sea which was about to engulf him </s>
<s> he spent week at pisa employed in kind offices toward his friend and enjoying with keen delight the renewal of their intercourse </s>
<s> he then embarked with mr williams the chosen and beloved sharer of his pleasures and of his fate to return to us </s>
<s> we waited for them in vain the sea by its restless moaning seemed to desire to inform us of what we would not learn but veil may well be drawn over such misery </s>
<s> the real anguish of those moments transcended all the fictions that the most glowing imagination ever portrayed our seclusion the savage nature of the inhabitants of the surrounding villages and our immediate vicinity to the troubled sea combined to imbue with strange horror our days of uncertainty </s>
<s> the truth was at last known truth that made our loved and lovely italy appear tomb its sky pall </s>
<s> every heart echoed the deep lament and my only consolation was in the praise and earnest love that each voice bestowed and each countenance demonstrated for him we had lost not fondly hope for ever his unearthly and elevated nature is pledge of the continuation of his being although in an altered form </s>
<s> rome received his ashes they are deposited beneath its weed grown wall and the world's sole monument is enriched by his remains </s>
<s> must add few words concerning the contents of this volume </s>
<s> julian and maddalo the witch of atlas and most of the translations were written some years ago and with the exception of the cyclops and the scenes from the magico prodigioso may be considered as having received the author's ultimate corrections </s>
<s> the triumph of life was his last work and was left in so unfinished state that arranged it in its present form with great difficulty </s>
<s> all his poems which were scattered in periodical works are collected in this volume and have added reprint of alastor or the spirit of solitude the difficulty with which copy can be obtained is the cause of its republication </s>
<s> many of the miscellaneous poems written on the spur of the occasion and never retouched found among his manuscript books and have carefully copied </s>
<s> have subjoined whenever have been able the date of their composition </s>
<s> do not know whether the critics will reprehend the insertion of some of the most imperfect among them but frankly own that have been more actuated by the fear lest any monument of his genius should escape me than the wish of presenting nothing but what was complete to the fastidious reader </s>
<s> feel secure that the lovers of shelley's poetry who know how more than any poet of the present day every line and word he wrote is instinct with peculiar beauty will pardon and thank me consecrate this volume to them </s>
<s> the size of this collection has prevented the insertion of any prose pieces </s>
<s> they will hereafter appear in separate publication </s>
